title: 108_hr4772
content: The "Terrorism Risk Insurance Program Extension Act of 2004" extends the program for specific years, including Program Year 4, Program Year 5, and the Final Program Year. Paragraph (5) of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to define 'insured loss' as any loss resulting from an act of terrorism covered by property and casualty insurance. The Final Program Year refers to losses covered by property and casualty insurance issued before January 1, 2008, and expiring by December 31, 2008. SEC. 4. INSURER DEDUCTIBLE. Paragraph (7) of section 102 of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to adjust the insurer deductible percentages for Program Years 3, 4, and 5, and the Final Program Year. The insurer's direct earned premiums for remaining policy terms under described insurance policies are multiplied by 15 percent after an act of terrorism, as determined by the Secretary. SEC. 5. MANDATORY AVAILABILITY. Amends subsection (c) of section 103 of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 to require mandatory availability for insurers meeting certain criteria during a specified period. SEC. 6. INSURED LOSS SHARED COMPENSATION. SEC. 6. INSURED LOSS SHARED COMPENSATION. Amends section 103 of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act to include coverage for Program Year 4, Program Year 5, and the Final Program Year. SEC. 7. COVERAGE OF GROUP LIFE INSURANCE. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to include group life insurance coverage in various sections. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to include group life insurance coverage in various sections, such as defining group life insurance coverage within the Program and including it in property and casualty insurance policies. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 now includes group life insurance coverage, expanding beyond property and casualty insurance. SEC. 8. TERMINATION OF PROGRAM. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to extend the termination date to December 31, 2008. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a final study and report to Congress by June 30, 2007.
